title: 112_s467
content: The Act titled "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" aims to enhance the Earned Income Tax Credit. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" includes a permanent extension of marriage penalty relief and an increase in credit for certain families. This involves reducing the marriage penalty and increasing the credit percentage for families with 3 or more children. The amendment in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increases the credit percentage for families with 3 or more children. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" includes a permanent extension of marriage penalty relief and an increase in credit percentage for families with 3 or more qualifying children, totaling 45 at 21.06%. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" includes a permanent extension of marriage penalty relief and an increase in credit for individuals with no qualifying children to $12,690. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" includes amendments to increase the credit for individuals with no children and certain childless individuals over age 21 under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" amends Section 32(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include a provision for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" amends Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by eliminating the disqualified investment income test and making conforming amendments related to married individuals living apart with a qualifying child. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" amends Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by simplifying rules regarding the presence of a qualifying child and making conforming amendments related to rounding dollar amounts in subsections. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" amends Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow taxpayers to claim a credit for a worker without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. The Act "Strengthen the Earned Income Tax Credit Act of 2011" allows taxpayers to claim a credit for a worker without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. If an eligible individual does not claim a qualifying child, they may still be considered eligible for the credit. If a parent claims a child as a qualifying child, no other parent can claim the child for the credit. The Act increases the penalty for failure to determine eligibility for the Earned Income Credit from $100 to $500. The effective dates for these amendments are for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010, and the increased penalty applies to returns filed after December 31, 2011. Additionally, the repeal of the sunset provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 does not apply to section 303 of the Act.
